pull.title: doc: add unittest core dump instructions
pull.body: Quick note on how to get core dumps out of the unittests.

events.body:
Concept ACK

Possible follow-ups:
* move 2nd and 3rd paragraph into more general documentation section; IMHO knowing how to find causes for crashes is useful not only for the unit-tests, but also for all other binaries that potentially segfault
* ~~also describe how to analyze core-dumps via `lldb` (if clang is used rather than gcc)~~

> describe how to analyze core-dumps via lldb (if clang is used rather than gcc)

FWIW gdb analyzes clang-built core dumps just fine for me, but maybe you meant something different.

> > describe how to analyze core-dumps via lldb (if clang is used rather than gcc)
> 
> FWIW gdb analyzes clang-built core dumps just fine for me, but maybe you meant something different.

Oh, it seems I had an ancient gdb version installed on my system, that didn't support the right DWARF version (leading me to the wrong conclusion that for clang-built core dump analysis only lldb works -- d'oh!). 

ACK bbeec50921c2cfcf054ba843bda392d310de5782 ðŸ“œ
Thanks for adding this. Testing the instructions.
ACK with two suggestions (one above, one below)

review ACK bbeec50921c2cfcf054ba843bda392d310de5782

Personally I just use valgrind which will print the stack when the dump is created
Ready for merge? Or I can add a note about valgrind?

This seems like a helpful improvement.

re-ACK modulo suggestions

almost re-ACK (linter is not happy yet)

Also I agree that the other suggestions by jonatack above (https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/22226#discussion_r678116566, https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/22226#discussion_r678119277) should be tackled.
LGTM, but yes it's failing the linters.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -74,3 +74,20 @@ start debugging, just like you would with any other program:
 ```bash
 gdb src/test/test_bitcoin
 ```
+
+#### Segmentation faults
+
+By default, the boost test runner will intercept system errors and not produce a core
+file. To bypass this, add `--catch_system_errors=no` to the `test_bitcoin` arguments
+and ensure that your ulimits are set properly (e.g. `ulimit -c unlimited`). 
+
+Running the tests and hitting a segmentation fault should now produce a file called `core`
+(depending upon your `/proc/sys/kernel/core_pattern` contents).
comments.body: Non-blocking nit: Could clarify that `/proc/sys/kernel/core_pattern` is Linux specific :)

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -74,3 +74,29 @@ start debugging, just like you would with any other program:
 ```bash
 gdb src/test/test_bitcoin
 ```
+
+#### Segmentation faults
+
+If you hit a segmentation fault during a test run, you can diagnose where the fault
+is happening by running `gdb ./src/test/test_bitcoin` and then using the `bt` command
+within gdb.
+
+Another tool that can be used to resolve segmentation faults is
+[valgrind](https://valgrind.org/).
+
+If for whatever reason you want to produce a core dump file for this fault, you can do
+that as well. By default, the boost test runner will intercept system errors and not
comments.body:

```suggestion
that as well. By default, the Boost test runner will intercept system errors and not
```

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -74,3 +74,29 @@ start debugging, just like you would with any other program:
 ```bash
 gdb src/test/test_bitcoin
 ```
+
+#### Segmentation faults
+
+If you hit a segmentation fault during a test run, you can diagnose where the fault
+is happening by running `gdb ./src/test/test_bitcoin` and then using the `bt` command
+within gdb.
+
+Another tool that can be used to resolve segmentation faults is
+[valgrind](https://valgrind.org/).
+
+If for whatever reason you want to produce a core dump file for this fault, you can do
+that as well. By default, the boost test runner will intercept system errors and not
+produce a core file. To bypass this, add `--catch_system_errors=no` to the
+`test_bitcoin` arguments and ensure that your ulimits are set properly (e.g. `ulimit -c
+unlimited`).
+
+Running the tests and hitting a segmentation fault should now produce a file called `core`
+(on Linux platforms, the file name will likely depend on the contents of

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -74,3 +74,29 @@ start debugging, just like you would with any other program:
 ```bash
 gdb src/test/test_bitcoin
 ```
+
+#### Segmentation faults
+
+If you hit a segmentation fault during a test run, you can diagnose where the fault
+is happening by running `gdb ./src/test/test_bitcoin` and then using the `bt` command
+within gdb.
+
+Another tool that can be used to resolve segmentation faults is
+[valgrind](https://valgrind.org/).
+
+If for whatever reason you want to produce a core dump file for this fault, you can do
+that as well. By default, the boost test runner will intercept system errors and not
+produce a core file. To bypass this, add `--catch_system_errors=no` to the
+`test_bitcoin` arguments and ensure that your ulimits are set properly (e.g. `ulimit -c
+unlimited`).
+
+Running the tests and hitting a segmentation fault should now produce a file called `core`
+(on Linux platforms, the file name will likely depend on the contents of 
+`/proc/sys/kernel/core_pattern`).
+
+You can then explore the core dump using
+``` bash
+gdb src/test/test_bitcoin core

@@ -74,3 +74,29 @@ start debugging, just like you would with any other program:

+
+#### Segmentation faults
+
+If you hit a segmentation fault during a test run, you can diagnose where the fault
+is happening by running `gdb ./src/test/test_bitcoin` and then using the `bt` command
+within gdb.
+
+Another tool that can be used to resolve segmentation faults is
+[valgrind](https://valgrind.org/).
+
+If for whatever reason you want to produce a core dump file for this fault, you can do
+that as well. By default, the boost test runner will intercept system errors and not
+produce a core file. To bypass this, add `--catch_system_errors=no` to the
+`test_bitcoin` arguments and ensure that your ulimits are set properly (e.g. `ulimit -c
+unlimited`).
+
+Running the tests and hitting a segmentation fault should now produce a file called `core`
+(on Linux platforms, the file name will likely depend on the contents of 
+`/proc/sys/kernel/core_pattern`).
+
+You can then explore the core dump using
+``` bash
+gdb src/test/test_bitcoin core
